metadata.title: Influence of Scanning on Nano Crystalline -Ti Alloys Fabricated by Selective Laser Melting and Their Applications in Biomedical Science

sections.text:

Article Journal of
Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Vol. 20, 1605–1612, 2020
www.aspbs.com/jnn
Influence of Scanning on Nano Crystalline -Ti Alloys Fabricated by Selective Laser Melting and Their
Applications in Biomedical Science
Lamei Yan1 ∗, Jianghong Yu2 3 ∗, Yuxing Zhong1, Yan Gu1, Yunpeng Ma1, Wenxin Li1, Jia Yan1, Yunyang Ge1, Junhui Yin1, Yuxiao Luo1, A. Mirzasadeghi4, and Youwei Yuan1
1School of Digital Media and Design, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China 2Hunan Province Key Laboratory of Safety Design and Reliability Technology for Engineering Vehicle,
Changsha University of Science & Technology, Changsha, 410114, China 3College of Mechanical Engineering, Hunan University of Technology, Zhuzhou, 412007, China
4Department of Orthopedics, School of Medicine, Taylor’s University, Level 9D, Hospital Sungai Buloh, 47000 Sungai Buloh, Selangor, Malaysia
The present study focuses on the microstructural and bioactive properties evolution in selective laser melting (SLM) titanium alloys. We have applied cross-scan strategy for improving mechanical properties and lower elastic modulus of SLMed Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys which has been shown to be altering the microstructure and refining the grain size. The cross-scan strategy can refine the microstructure and induce various deformation textures in contrast to the conventional scan strategy. The microstructures of Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys indicate that the cross-scan strategy will yield the best mechanical properties and lower elastic modulus. The corrosion behavior of the Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys was studied during immersion in an acellular simulated body fluid (SBF) at 37±0.50 C for 28 days. Both the mechanical and bioactive properties showed that the novel Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys should be ideal for bone implants.
Keywords: Cross Scanning, Selective Laser Melting (SLM), Biomedical Applications, Titanium Alloys, Scan Strategy.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
The combination of biomechanical compatibility and low elastic modulus contributing to high mechanical and bioactive properties makes the -Ti alloys promising for biomedical applications [1–12]. The high bio-degradability low modulus (−40 GPa) of Mg makes it attractive for biomedical applications such as resorbable bolts, screws and biodegradable orthopaedic implants [13–23]. Currently, the most commonly applied orthopaedics biomaterials are pure titanium and the Ti6Al4V alloys which are used to manufacture components of dentistry, bone screw and bone implants. The -stabilizing elements, such as Cr, Ta, Mo and Zr, are applied as safe alloying elements to titanium which are proved to be non-allergic and nontoxic [24–29]. Moreover, alloys have better mechanical
∗Authors to whom correspondence should be addressed.
properties and lower elastic modulus than or + alloys [30–32]. Recent, more and more metal nanomaterials with excel-
lent properties are emerging constantly with the development of nanotechnology, which make great progress in biomedical materials and medical fluorescent materials [33–41]. Developments in selective laser melting (SLM) have gained considerable interest due to their ability to fabricate various shaped components [42–47]. Research is focus on the SLM fabrication parameter, microstructural features and mechanical response as well as scanning strategies process parameters on phase transformation behavior and temperatures [48, 49]. The growing interest in selective laser melting has generated a need for developing a detailed understanding of successful processing techniques to both for enhancing the material properties and reducing production costs [50, 51].
J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 2020, Vol. 20, No. 3 1533-4880/2020/20/1605/008 doi:10.1166/jnn.2020.17340 1605
IP: 85.202.194.26 On: Wed, 01 Jan 2020 17:05:50 Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
Delivered by Ingenta
We previously developed new biocompatible SLMed Ti–15Ta–xZr and Ti–20Nb–12Ta–0.5Zr alloys for biomedical application [52, 53]. For this study, the reason for choosing Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys compositions is based on our previous research outputs and countless experiments. We suggest applying the cross-scan strategy and HotIsostatic Pressing (HIP) post-treatment to eliminate nonhomogeneities and discoloration. This study will focus on microstructure and texture of SLMed Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys with considering different fabrication parameters as well as scanning strategies.

sections.heading: 2.1. Powder Preparation
sections.text: The Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloy materials used in the selective laser melting was gas atomized 99.9% pure Titanium, Magnesium Tantalum powders (obtained from Alfa Aesar) with nearly spherical particles having an average diameter of 45 m.

sections.heading: 2.2. SLM and HIP Process
sections.text:
The Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys samples were manufactured using SLM® 500 equipped with a Nd-YAG fiber laser. The set was provided with Power input of 9 kW along with beam diameter, scanning speed, hatch spacing, layer thickness and build rate of 105 m, 8.8 m/s, 110 m, 55 m and 160 cm3/h, respectively. The SLM and HIP process is shown in Figure 1. The E-Connection was 400 Volt 3NPE, 64 A, 50 HZ. HIP was subsequently used to improve the microstructure and texture of the SLMed Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys. Heating for 3 h at 650 C and pressure of 185 MPa of Ar gas (HP-99.99%) followed by quenching cooling to air temperature at a rate of 35 C/min. Figure 2 shows the schematic representation of the bidirectional cross-scan strategy of the SLM process in the current study. The cubical specimens of 80×80×80 mm3 were produced to investigate the microstructural characteristics. The as-built samples of sample I, sample II, sample III were used the different scanning strategy. Sample I was manufactured
by our designed cross-scan method as shown in Figure 2. While, sample II and III were built by vertical and parallel scan strategies, respectively. After SLM, the specimens were removed from the substrate by an electro-discharge machining (EDM). Each batch of samples was made up of 40 specimens.

sections.heading: 2.3. Microstructural Observation
sections.text: The SLMed Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys samples were polished and were etched for 30 s in a mixed solution comprising of 0 g FeCl3, 3 mL H2SO4, 55 mL H2O2, 55 mL deionized H2O. The phases of the bulk samples were examined through X-ray diffraction (XRD-6100). The microstructures of the samples were conducted using a scanning electron microscopy system (FlexSEM 1000). The electron backscattered diffraction analysis (EBSD) was analyzed on FEI/Nova Nano SEM equipped with an HKL Channel 5 system.

sections.heading: 2.4. Bioactivity Test
sections.text: Above Cube specimens with dimensions of 80 mm× 80 mm× 80 mm3 were cut into 4× 4× 2 mm3 plates. In order to study the bioactivity of Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys of sample I. Immersion testing was conducted in 5 mL of an acellular simulated body fluid (SBF) at 37 ± 0.5 C for 28 days. The SBF was prepared according to the ASTM G31-72 standard by mixing kHCO3, NaCl, Na2SO4, MgCl2, CaCl2 · 6H2O in ultra-pure water and buffered at pH 7.4 using tris (hydroxymethyl)-aminoethane (Sigma Aldrich) and 2 M HCl. After the immersion test, the Ti–20Mg–5Ta sample was cleaned using ultra-pure water.

sections.heading: 3.1. Microstructural Characterization and Alloys Phase Transformation
sections.text:
Figure 3 shows the SEM micrographs of the Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys SLMed samples. The red arrow indicates the SLM
1606 J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 20, 1605–1612, 2020
IP: 85.202.194.26 On: Wed, 01 Jan 2020 17:05:50 Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
Delivered by Ingenta
building direction. (a) Sample I, (b) sample II, (c) sample III. Figure 4 illustrates the XRD patterns of the SLMed samples fabricated with different strategies. It is evident that the peak of the phase in SLMed samples I is stronger than sample II and III. There are 2 and 3 peaks corresponding to phase in sample II and III, respectively. The XRD spectra revealed that the sample I using the cross-scan method is stable phase as the cross-scan method can melt the alloys powder completely and can eliminated phase. The Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys with stable phase exhibited lower modulus than that of conventional Ti-based alloys.
Figure 5 illustrated the elemental EDX microanalyses of the fracture surface of the SLMed Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys samples. (a) Sample I, (b) sample II, (c) sample III. Clearly, the applied different scan strategies have major
influence on porosity and pore morphology. The crosssectional microstructures of the components fabricated samples II using the vertical-scanning strategy and the sample III using parallel-scanning strategy contained many unmelted particle clusters along with some interconnected pores and cavities of −30±0.28 m (sample I) and 60± 0.52 m (sample II) on average. The results showed that the sample I obtained using cross-scan strategy exhibited the highest densification 95± 0.42%, while the densification of sample II using vertical-scan strategy is 84±0.41% and the sample III using parallel-scan strategy is 73± 0.39%. It is possible that the SLM process using crossscan strategy can completely melt the Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloy powders contributing towards highest densification.

sections.heading: 3.2. EBSD Analysis
sections.text: Figure 6 shows the EBSD orientation image maps of sample I, II, III. Crystal orientation maps: the blue, red, green color corresponds to the [111], [001], [101] directions, respectively. The inverse pole figure (IPF) shown in the middle of the Figure 6 illustrates relationship between the colors used in the EBSD maps and crystal orientations in the SLM-processed Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys samples. The average grain size of sample I is 0.36± 0.21 m, compared to 0.77± 0.31 m in sample II and 1.98± 0.52 m in sample III. The difference between the grain sizes of samples can be attributed to the different scanning strategies.

sections.heading: 3.3. Comparison of Mechanical Properties
sections.text:
During Selective laser melting process, the temperature rise T of the selective laser beam center is computed as follows [53, 54].
T = AP √ k ∫ 0
d 1/2 1+4 exp (−v∗2 2 1+4 ) (1)
where A represents the laser absorption of alloys, k refers to the thermal conductivity (W/(m ·K)), P stands for the selective laser melting laser power (W), v is the laser scanning velocity (mm/s), is the laser spot radius (mm), while v∗ and are scanning velocity and v∗ = v / ( represents the thermal diffusivity (m2/s)) and dimensionless variables, respectively. Figure 7 shows the laser absorptions of Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys. It is indicted that the laser absorptions of Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys in sample I is much better than sample II and III. The true stress–strain curves are shown in Figure 8. Mechanical properties of the three Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys samples with cpTi biomaterial material are summarized in Table I. Comparison of mechanical properties of the SLMed Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys samples is shown in Figure 9. The results revealed that sample 1 had the highest Ultimate tensile strength (UTS) at 1089.26± 21.4 Mpa, Yield strength (YS) at 989.15± 16.25 Mpa and Elongation (EL) of 20.12± 3.26. When compared
J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 20, 1605–1612, 2020 1607
with the cpTi biomaterial, the UTS increased by 54.90%, YS increased by 59.65% and EL increased by 287.69%, respectively. The Young’s modulus value for sample I, sample II, and sample III were 43.18± 9.01 GPa, 68.9± 3.02 GPa,
72.6±3.52 GPa, respectively. Particularly, the sample I had a very good value of Young’s modulus. The results revealed that Young’s modulus value of the sample I significantly decreases and mechanical properties increases compared to the cpTi biomaterial material.

sections.heading: 3.4. Evaluation of Biocompatibility
sections.text:
As discussed above, sample I had good mechanical properties and lower Young’s modulus value. Therefore, we evaluated the corrosion behavior of the Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys of sample I. Figure 10 shows the EDS elemental maps of Ti, Mg and Ta shown in transversal cross-section of the Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys composite of sample I diluted in SBF for 28 days. The dashed lines represent the surface. Figure 11 shows the weight loss and degradation rate (DR) of the Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys composites of sample I

Figure 9. Comparison of mechanical properties of the SLMed Ti– 20Mg–5Ta alloys samples.
Figure 10. EDS elemental maps of Ti, Mg and Ta shown in transversal cross-section of the Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys composite diluted in SBF for 28 days. The dashed lines represent the surface of the sample I.
after dilution in SBF for 28 days. The dilution of Ti– 20Mg–5Ta alloys in the transversal direction proceeded down to −55 m. The typical diameter of a bone screw is 7–9 mm. It shows that the Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys has

the good corrosion resistance. Figure 12 shows the surface morphology of the Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys after immersion test (a) 15 days SBF immersion, (b) 28 days SBF immersion.

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
In the present study, we have developed a novel Ti–20Mg– 5Ta alloys via selective laser melting for orthopaedic applications. The advantage of the new developed crossscanning strategy compared to the conventional strategies are remarkable mechanical properties and lower elastic modulus. The cross-scan strategy can refine the microstructure and induce various deformation textures in contrast to the conventional scanning strategies. In addition, the developed cross-scan strategy is possible to change alloys from phase and phase and finally into stable phase as cross-scan can completely melt the alloys powder and eliminate phase. The Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys with stable phase exhibited lower modulus than that of conventional Ti-based alloys. We have obtained the result that the applied different scan strategies have a major influence on mechanical properties and appropriate elastic modulus. The densification level was mainly influenced by different scanning strategy. Densification 95± 0.42% was achieved using the cross-scanning strategy compared to vertical and parallel scanning strategy. It is possible that the SLM process using cross-scan strategy can completely melt the Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys powder, contributing the highest densification. The newly developed Ti–20Mg–5Ta alloys have demonstrated themselves as promising candidate of biomedical materials with outstanding mechanical properties and lower elastic modulus.
Acknowledgments: The work was supported by the Natural Science Foundation of Zhejiang Province (LY17E050027).

referenceMentions.context: Research is focus on the SLM fabrication parameter, microstructural features and mechanical response as well as scanning strategies process parameters on phase transformation behavior and temperatures [48, 49].

Research is focus on the SLM fabrication parameter, microstructural features and mechanical response as well as scanning strategies process parameters on phase transformation behavior and temperatures [48, 49].

The growing interest in selective laser melting has generated a need for developing a detailed understanding of successful processing techniques to both for enhancing the material properties and reducing production costs [50, 51].

The growing interest in selective laser melting has generated a need for developing a detailed understanding of successful processing techniques to both for enhancing the material properties and reducing production costs [50, 51].
